answers.answer:
Newcomers in Suceava can access assistance including temporary protection, free public transport for Ukrainian refugees, medical and psychological support, and educational opportunities. Additionally, various organizations provide material support, legal aid, and specialized counseling services.

To find detailed information, refer to the provided summary's sections such as "Temporary protection", "Transportation", "Medical services", "Psychological support", "Education", and "Organisations offering their support". For even more details, visit the website dopomoha.ro/en/dopomoha-suceava and navigate through the relevant sections.

People living with HIV in Romania can receive free, anonymous, and confidential psycho-medical-social services from specialist doctors at 10 Regional HIV Centers in Romania, with support from Sens Pozitiv.

To find more detailed information, visit the website https://dopomoha.ro/en/dopomoha-suceava and look under the section titled "Counseling for people living with HIV."

Yes, there are services specifically for vulnerable groups. The Bucovina Institute Association facilitates access to resources for categories of refugees from vulnerable groups, including people with disabilities and unaccompanied minors. Additionally, Terre des hommes Foundation offers psychological assistance, which includes unaccompanied children.

To find detailed information, you would need to visit the original webpage from which this summary was extracted (likely dopomoha.ro/en/dopomoha-suceava) and look under the sections "Psychological support" and "Organisations offering their support" for the contact details and specific services of Terre des hommes Foundation and The Bucovina Institute Association, respectively.
